title: 108_s822
content: The "Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2003" may be cited as the Short Title. It establishes the Child Care Business Loan Program. The "Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2003" establishes the Child Care Business Loan Program under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, amending section 502 to authorize loans with restrictions and limitations. The Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2003 establishes the Child Care Business Loan Program under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, allowing loans for small, non-profit child care businesses with specific eligibility requirements. The Small Business Administration is required to provide reports every 6 months after the enactment of the Act. The Small Business Administration must submit reports every 6 months on the implementation of the Child Care Business Loan Program under the Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2003. The reports should include the program implementation date, rules issuance date, and details on the number and amount of loans applied for and approved. The Small Business Administration must provide reports every 6 months on the Child Care Business Loan Program, including the date of program implementation, rules issuance, and details on loan applications and approvals. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report on the program to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business by March 31, 2006, containing information from the first 2 years of the loan program. The report to the House of Representatives on the Child Care Business Loan Program should include an evaluation of program implementation, participation of Certified Development Companies, lenders, and small businesses, marketing strategies, and the number of child care businesses applying for and receiving loans. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will issue final rules within 120 days of the enactment of the Act to implement the loan program authorized by section 502(b)(1)(B) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The report on the Child Care Business Loan Program should evaluate program implementation, participation of Certified Development Companies, lenders, marketing strategies, and the number of child care businesses applying for and receiving loans. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will issue final rules to implement the loan program authorized by section 502(b)(1)(B) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The amendments made by this section will be in effect until September 30, 2006, applying to loans made during the period from enactment of the Act to September 30, 2006.
